Thanks for the thoughtful feedback, ScienceDuck. 

We do worry about people always marking perfectly fine comments as "uncivil", and take false-negative civility votes as seriously as false-positives. We are as concerned about people unfairly silencing opposing views as we are about uncivil comments getting through.

The problem with letting bad voting slide, though, is that personal attacks and spam comments are still getting through too often. And by the time they're seen and flagged, the damage is, largely, already done. (People also abuse the flag button to attack people with whom they disagree; this just ends up negatively impacting the bad-flagger's own trust rating, but it's still a concern). 

I do sincerely appreciate the feedback, though; we're trying to find ways to improve behavior without being too extreme. When warnings aren't enough to correct the issue, though, we thought a 24-hour rate-limited restriction (not a ban) might help.
